data: I‚Äôve finished my PhD! Despite the virus, in March I had the viva and submitted my corrections. Which means that as of this month ( specifically April 1st !) it‚Äôs all finished and the certificate should be in the post. In case you missed it, here is my recap detailing the rather strange end to my PhD. I‚Äôve hinted in the past that I planned to take a 1-2 year break to travel after finishing the PhD. Unsurprisingly, this is now on hold for the moment. In this post I‚Äôll cover what I‚Äôm doing instead and set this in the context of my longer term aspirations which I‚Äôve never discussed here before. Contents Toggle My long term career plans At the heart of it, I want to be able to do a job that I enjoy, working for causes that I feel passionate about. This doesn‚Äôt sound very unusual, I‚Äôd hope most people set out to do fulfilling work that they enjoy. Sadly in my experience many people get sidetracked by money or feel unable to make bold career moves. Absolutely central to having so much freedom is to have a savings safety net. Over the past few years I‚Äôve gradually built up my savings and lowered my expenses (2019 report here ). In the short term having savings means I can afford to support myself without immediately seeking out another job. In the long term this affords me the option to move around, take lower-paid jobs I care about, take risks and try different things or even take voluntary (unpaid) positions to build up experience. Read more about financial freedom here or the Mr. Money Mustache blog which takes it even further. One of the things which appeals to me most about financial freedom is being able to afford to work part time at your main job if you choose. This could provide you with a good amount of time each week to concentrate on other projects you feel strongly about, even potentially building up a ‚Äúportfolio career‚Äù. It would be great to be able to continue spending time helping students on this website, whilst at the same time picking up a few other projects which can help in other fields. What I care about I care about two main things: people and the planet. I don‚Äôt know exactly what I‚Äôll be doing in 10 years time, but I know that I‚Äôm passionate about these two main causes and want to play my part in making the world a better place. That sounds very non-committal, but this means that I have some scope to try out a huge range of different fields. Potential fields of work Fields on my radar which I‚Äôve been considering going into include: Coral reef restoration (full post here ) Economic sustainability / Green banking Urban food growing Fighting human exploitation Reforestation Lab grown meat production Fighting exploitation of natural resources All things ‚Äúlevelling the playing field‚Äù such as fighting racial or sexual discrimination Personal finance empowerment Or simply carrying on in the field of my PhD: regenerative medicine A pretty diverse list! They‚Äôre all tied together by the central idea of trying to help make the world a better place. I love coral! Read about a scholarship I was fortunate to receive to go to Fiji and help on this project, here . How could I help? You may have noticed that the list above doesn‚Äôt actually state jobs, they‚Äôre fields or aims. Of course it‚Äôd be no good me saying I want to fight exploitation in court: I‚Äôm not a lawyer! There are other ways to get involved though, in the case of fighting exploitation that could be: Using novel methods to track and/or stop it close to the source Uncovering and analysing data to assess prevalence and focus resources Raising awareness and public support by reporting as a journalist (shoutout to Ronan Farrow ) or filmmaker Even introducing policy: though please stop me from pursuing politics! I don‚Äôt believe that people should have to ‚Äústay in their lane‚Äù and stick to the profession they trained in: sometimes tackling a problem from a new angle can help. You probably have some complimentary skills from another discipline which could be applied. I believe that having a passion for something is likely reason enough to spend your time on it. If you care about a cause there is a way to apply your enthusiasm to help. Where could I work? Academia ‚Äì there are no shortage of research groups working on things I care about. In the short term doing a postdoc somewhere could be a handy way to see another part of the world and build my skills while contributing to the field. Business ‚Äì I feel like I could have very fulfilling careers working in a huge range of companies, ranging from eco-web search company Ecosia , ethical banking company Triodos through to fighting sexual exploitation with Thorn . Social enterprise / Charity ‚Äì Corals for Conservation (group I helped in Fiji), Migrateful , 38 Degrees or a whole host of other charities and social enterprises could make for interesting work. How about starting my own company? I‚Äôm not at all opposed to starting my own company or social enterprise if there is a niche not currently being well served. At the moment though the idea of raising funding and being responsible for salaries (especially with an impending financial downturn!) doesn‚Äôt sound at all fun to me. Potentially starting with lifestyle business (which are much more modest) currently sounds more appealing to dip my toes in and is something I‚Äôm considering. So as you can see, I‚Äôm not 100% set on staying on academia, but that is not to say the PhD wasn‚Äôt worth doing. Will my PhD be useful? Unlike other PhD students, who may have a very focussed aim of becoming an academic afterwards (see the piece with one such PhD student here ), I‚Äôm not sure whether academia is right for me long term. I don‚Äôt dislike the idea, but I‚Äôm certainly much less sold on it than I was at the start. I‚Äôve seen how competitive funding applications are even once you‚Äôve ‚Äúmade it‚Äù and I am all too aware of how slow the pace of progress is. I may end up going in to careers where having a PhD isn‚Äôt necessary but I know that it will have been useful. All the points in this post about why I decided to do a PhD still hold true, I enjoyed the research which is enough. For my own personal growth it has been fantastic, I learned new skills, gained confidence and frankly now won‚Äôt be stuck wondering if I should have done one. One of the main skills the PhD has been really beneficial for has been presenting and of course is useful for every career. I still get really nervous presenting but now have the confidence to know I can do it. Additionally, many of the fields I‚Äôm considering are both science-orientated and technical. Having a PhD will be a fantastic asset in practically every role for the fields I‚Äôm interested in. There is no doubt that for better or worse simply having a PhD is useful and points towards technical competence, even if you‚Äôre switching fields. Why I‚Äôm not staying on in the research group Before recent events, I‚Äôd said to my supervisor that I wasn‚Äôt interested in staying on in the research group. This was for a few reasons: I wanted to take a career break and go travelling. I felt satisfied with where I‚Äôd finished my work. It‚Äôs not like staying on for another year or two would have drastically progressed my PhD work. I knew I didn‚Äôt want to stay in London long term. I‚Äôd like to be able settle down and buy a home at some point and don‚Äôt really fancy getting locked in to a 25 year mortgage paying ¬£400,000 or more for a small apartment. As shown by the list above, I‚Äôm interested in a diverse range of fields. Almost all of them are either more impactful (in my opinion), or help a wider range of people, than my PhD work. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôd be satisfied if I don‚Äôt at least spend a bit of time trying to help with some of them. Further to this, I knew that if I stayed in the group as a postdoc it would then be all too tempting to apply for fellowships or lecturer positions and never end up going travelling. Why would I make myself voluntarily unemployed? A few main reasons: I was expecting to take a break after my PhD and don‚Äôt want to go straight in to something So that I can take a low-risk chance on new ideas I‚Äôm not anxious in my ability to find a job I don‚Äôt need the money I want to be able to carry on with my travel plans immediately once things settle down Of course I don‚Äôt know exactly how long the current situation will last for, but I‚Äôm in the extremely fortunate position (savings, low rent and no social pressure) to be under no obligation to need a job for the sake of making money. I‚Äôve shared this article before but it‚Äôs worth sharing again. Disregarding the slight irony that some people may see getting a PhD as a big fat badge itself, the main point to take away from that article is that ambitious people should feel able to take risks. That‚Äôs one of main reasons I feel so strongly about financial freedom and I am so thankful to be in a position where I don‚Äôt have to have a job to make ends meet. What about gaps on my CV? I‚Äôm not in the least bit worried about not being employed at the moment. In addition to the positive reasons above for why I‚Äôm taking a break, I‚Äôm not sure if I‚Äôll ever be working in a conventional workplace where taking a break may count against me. Plus these are really unusual times, I think recruiters will look on this period very differently to usual, a lot of people are being disrupted. Part of the reason I‚Äôm beginning a series from now on to share my monthly plans is to track what I‚Äôm up to, ensuring I‚Äôm accountable for the new things I want to learn. I could always point potential employers here if it needed any justification, I‚Äôd expect most employers to respect this. If an employer takes issue with me taking some time off, learning new skills and evaluating what I want to do with my life then I probably don‚Äôt want to work for them. Short term plans: how I‚Äôm spending to my time now Now that I‚Äôm not able to travel, I‚Äôve temporarily moved in with my girlfriend and her family. Besides a few weeks of casual employment to work on papers I haven‚Äôt tried to get reemployed by the university since the lockdown. Instead what I want to do with my time here in the UK before travelling is: Take a break Improve my skills Develop this website further Finish off a few papers (at my own pace) Consider new ideas, projects or opportunities Taking a break most definitely involves baking: We just made a double-batch of @thehappypear oat cookies and can confirm that they're very tasty! üç™üòÅ https://t.co/7ubmbGP9C4 pic.twitter.com/BdPpR0NMpi ‚Äî Jeff Clark (@savvy_scientist) April 12, 2020 Improving my skills There are some skills I fancy dedicating some time to because of one of the following reasons: May help in future jobs They sound fun Could be useful in life I‚Äôm intrigued and simply fancy learning for the joy of it Currently this list of skills includes: Creating visual content: painting, animation (Blender) and videos Meditation Coding: Python, making apps and getting an introduction to machine learning Baking bread Statistics for large datasets I started learning handstands just before COVID-19 but this is currently on hold because I‚Äôm scared of breaking myself and needing to go to hospital! I‚Äôd love to learn backflips but yeah no, I‚Äôm not risking them at the moment! We live in an amazing time where new skills in practically every domain can be learned for free online. I want to make good use of this myself, starting now. There are loads of free online courses available for practically every topic. Coursera , Codecademy, Skillshare are just three. Maybe some of these will be useful in the future, maybe not, but I want to spend some time trying them out and now seems like a good time. Further to this, the barriers to getting involved, sharing your ideas or starting a new business are becoming obsolete. You can start a YouTube channel with just your phone or self-publish a book with minimal upfront costs. Medium, WordPress and Twitter make sharing your thoughts simpler than ever. I‚Äôm looking at ways to expand my reach whilst learning new skills with these tools. The Savvy Scientist website I started this website to target the ‚Äúlevelling the playing field‚Äù goal: making information about PhDs more widely available, sharing my experiences with people who might not have immediate access to people who‚Äôve gone through the process. Neither of my parents went to university, so I‚Äôve personally benefitted from reading about other peoples‚Äô experiences online ‚Äì both at undergraduate level and postgraduate. It would be fantastic if I in turn could pass on my knowledge and help the next generation of scientists. I didn‚Äôt post here as frequently during my PhD as I would have liked, and I‚Äôd like to change this going forwards. Traffic is building every month and the feedback I‚Äôve received on the small amount of content I have here has been very useful. As well as hopefully giving an insight in to PhDs, the website is a good outlet for tracking my own ideas and thoughts whilst hopefully improving my writing. I‚Äôm playing with the idea of making videos to compliment the written content. Video content is becoming more and more popular so could help reach a larger audience plus video production is one of the skills I‚Äôd like to learn anyway. Staying Accountable Going forwards I plan to share a monthly update on what I‚Äôm up to. This will outline my goals for the next month and reflect on my progress from the month before. Update: The first of my monthly updates is now live here . This should help to keep me focussed on my long term goals and give a nice diary to be able to look back on to track progress. I fear that if I don‚Äôt set a plan, before I know it it‚Äôll be autumn and all I‚Äôll have done is watch every Bon Appetite video! You don‚Äôt need to have finished your PhD to plan for the future! Where do you wan t your career to go and what steps can you take to get there? I hope this post has inspired you to think about what you want to do with your career or inspired you to try learning a few new skills. I‚Äôll keep you updated on my progress.
